p.text: The Admiralty Act 1988 No 34 was assented to on 22 May 1988, commencing 1 January 1989. Since that date the Act has been amended by:

row.entry: Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Act 1989 No 151
Service and Execution of Process (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1992 No 166
International Maritime Conventions Legislation Amendment Act 2001 No 149
Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Act 2004 No 62
Jurisdiction of the Federal Magistrates Court Legislation Amendment Act 2006 No 23
Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability for Bunker Oil Pollution Damage) (Consequential Amendments) Act 2008 No 77
Personal Property Securities (Consequential Amendments) Act 2009 No 131
Federal Circuit Court of Australia (Consequential Amendments) Act 2013 No 13

p.text: AN ACT relating to Admiralty and maritime jurisdiction.
BE IT ENACTED by the Queen, and the Senate and the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, as follows:
This Act may be cited as the Admiralty Act 1988.
Legislation cited in [250,001.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 41(4), s 44(1), ss 9–12.
(CTH) Admiralty Rules 1988.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Section 5.

Formerly the Supreme Court derived its civil admiralty jurisdiction from the Colonial Courts of Admiralty Act 1890 (UK) which provided that the nature and extent of that jurisdiction was the court could “exercise such jurisdiction in like manner and to as full an extent as the High Court in England”. Criminal jurisdiction in admiralty, although its identity has not been wholly subsumed in the common law, has long been administered by common law judges: R v Bull (1974) 131 CLR 203 at 226; 3 ALR 171 . For civil proceedings commenced after 1 January 1989, s 44(1) of the Admiralty Act 1988 (Cth) effects the repeal of the UK legislation in its application to the Commonwealth of Australia and its territories. Admiralty jurisdiction under the Commonwealth Act is conferred on the Supreme Court by ss 9–12 and 41(4) — the latter of which relates to the Admiralty Rules 1988 (Cth) and broaden its scope: see Australian Law Reform Commission, Report No 33, Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction, 1986; S Hetherington, Annotated Admiralty Legislation, Law Book Co, Sydney, 1989; Sir Frederick Jordan, The Admiralty Jurisdiction in New South Wales, reprinted in Select Legal Papers, Sydney, 1983. Section 5 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 does not limit or increase any court’s jurisdiction in admiralty.
This Act commences on a day to be fixed by Proclamation.
In this Act, unless the contrary intention appears:
, when used in a geographical sense, includes each external Territory;
has the same meaning as the Convention has in the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981 .
[def subst Act 62 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 27 May 2004]
means:
the territorial sea of Australia; and
the sea on the landward side of the territorial sea of Australia and not within the limits of a State or Territory.
[def insrt Act 129 of 2012 Sch 2 item 1, effective 13 September 2012]
means the Federal Circuit Court of Australia.
[def insrt Act 13 of 2013 s 3 and Sch 1 item 25, effective 12 April 2013]
means the Federal Court of Australia;
includes passage money and hire;
means an air-cushion vehicle, or a similar vehicle, used wholly or principally in navigation by water;
includes a third party notice;
means waters within Australia other than waters of the sea;
means a vessel used or intended to be used wholly on inland waters;
means:
the Civil Liability Convention;
the Limitation Convention; or
any other international convention that is in force in relation to Australia and makes provision with respect to the limitation of liability in relation to maritime claims;
has the meaning given to the expression Convention by subsection 3(1) of the Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Act 1989.
[def subst Act 149 of 2001 s 3 and Sch 1 effective 13 May 2004]
means a proceeding under:
section 25 of this Act;
section 9 of the Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Act 1989; or
section 10 of the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981;
[def am Act 151 of 1989 s 12 and Sch 2]
, in relation to a ship, means a person who has command or charge of the ship;
, in relation to a ship, means a person employed or engaged in any capacity on board the ship on the business of the ship, other than:
the master of the ship;
a person who has the conduct of the ship as the pilot of the ship; or
a person temporarily employed on the ship in port;

, in relation to a ship or a share in a ship, includes a hypothecation or pledge of, and a charge on, the ship or share whether at law or in equity and whether arising under the law in force in a part of Australia or elsewhere;
means a structure (including a pipeline) that:
is fixed to the seabed and is not able to move or be moved as a structure from one place to another; and
is used or intended for use wholly or primarily in, or in any operations or activities associated with or incidental to, exploring or exploiting the mineral and other non-living resources of:
the continental shelf of Australia; or
the seabed of the coastal sea of Australia or the subsoil of that seabed.
[def insrt Act 129 of 2012 Sch 2 item 2, effective 13 September 2012]
means:

a vessel, or a structure other than a vessel that is able to float or be floated and to move or be moved as a structure from one place to another, that is used or intended for use wholly or primarily in, or in any operations or activities associated with or incidental to, exploring or exploiting the mineral and other non-living resources of:
the continental shelf of Australia; or
the seabed of the coastal sea of Australia or the subsoil of that seabed;
by drilling, or by obtaining substantial quantities of material from, the seabed or its subsoil, with equipment that is on or forms part of the vessel or structure; or

a barge or similar vessel fitted with living quarters for more than 12 persons and used or intended for use wholly or primarily in connection with the construction, maintenance or repair of off-shore industry fixed structures.
[def insrt Act 129 of 2012 Sch 2 item 3, effective 13 September 2012]
, in relation to a maritime claim, means a person who would be liable on the claim in a proceeding commenced as an action in personam;
includes all waters within the ebb and flow of the tide;
means a vessel of any kind used or constructed for use in navigation by water, however it is propelled or moved, and includes:
a barge, lighter or other floating vessel;
a hovercraft;
an off-shore industry mobile unit; and
a vessel that has sunk or is stranded and the remains of such a vessel;
but does not include:
a seaplane;
an inland waterways vessel; or
a vessel under construction that has not been launched;
[def am Act 129 of 2012 Sch 2 item 4, effective 13 September 2012]
includes the regulations and the Rules made under this Act.
A reference in this Act to the time when a proceeding is commenced is a reference to the time when the initiating process in relation to the proceeding is filed in, or issued by, a court.

A reference in this Act to goods, in relation to a ship, includes a reference to the baggage and other possessions of a person who is on the ship, being baggage and possessions that are being carried or are to be carried on the ship.
A reference in this Act to the entering of appearance includes a reference to any similar procedure.
A reference in this Act to the costs and expenses of the Marshal includes a reference to the amounts payable to a person acting in accordance with the Rules as a Marshal of a court.
For the purposes of this Act, where:
the other ship is, in relation to the claim, a surrogate ship.

In the context of an action in rem, the word “ship” includes all property aboard the ship other than that which is owned by a person not the owner of the ship: The Silia [1981] 2 Lloyd's Rep 534 at 537.

The words “would be liable on the claim” mean that, on a challenge to the court's jurisdiction, it is not appropriate to enter into the merits of an arresting party's in personam claim: KMP Coastal Oil Pty Ltd v Owners of MV Iran Amanat (1997) 75 FCR 78; 144 ALR 720 .
A reference in this Act to a maritime claim is a reference to a proprietary maritime claim or a general maritime claim.
A reference in this Act to a proprietary maritime claim is a reference to:
a claim relating to:
possession of a ship;
title to, or ownership of, a ship or a share in a ship;
a mortgage of a ship or of a share in a ship; or
a mortgage of a ship's freight;
a claim between co-owners of a ship relating to the possession, ownership, operation or earnings of the ship;

a claim for the satisfaction or enforcement of a judgment given by a court (including a court of a foreign country) against a ship or other property in a proceeding in rem in the nature of a proceeding in Admiralty; or
a claim for interest in respect of a claim referred to in paragraph (a) , (b) or (c) .
A reference in this Act to a general maritime claim is a reference to:
a claim for damage done by a ship (whether by collision or otherwise); or

a claim in respect of the liability of the owner of a ship arising under Part II or IV of the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981 or under a law of a State or Territory that makes provision as mentioned in subsection 7(1) of that Act; or
a claim under:
the applied provisions (within the meaning of the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability for Bunker Oil Pollution Damage) Act 2008); or
a law of a State or Territory of a kind referred to in subsection 10(1) of that Act; or
a claim for loss of life, or for personal injury, sustained in consequence of a defect in a ship or in the apparel or equipment of a ship; or
a claim (including a claim for loss of life or personal injury) arising out of an act or omission of:
the owner or charterer of a ship;
a person in possession or control of a ship; or
a person for whose wrongful acts or omissions the owner, charterer or person in possession or control of a ship is liable;
being an act or omission in the navigation or management of the ship, including an act or omission in connection with:
the loading of goods on to, or the unloading of goods from, the ship;
the embarkation of persons on to, or the disembarkation of persons from, the ship; and
the carriage of goods or persons on the ship; or
a claim for loss of, or damage to, goods carried by a ship; or
a claim arising out of an agreement that relates to the carriage of goods or persons by a ship or to the use or hire of a ship, whether by charterparty or otherwise; or
a claim relating to salvage (including life salvage and salvage of cargo or wreck found on land); or
a claim in respect of general average; or
a claim in respect of towage of a ship; or
a claim in respect of pilotage of a ship; or
a claim in respect of goods, materials or services (including stevedoring and lighterage services) supplied or to be supplied to a ship for its operation or maintenance; or
a claim in respect of the construction of a ship (including such a claim relating to a vessel before it was launched); or
a claim in respect of the alteration, repair or equipping of a ship; or
a claim in respect of a liability for port, harbour, canal or light tolls, charges or dues, or tolls, charges or dues of a similar kind, in relation to a ship; or

a claim in respect of a levy in relation to a ship, including a shipping levy imposed by the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Act 1981 , being a levy in relation to which a power to detain the ship is conferred by a law in force in Australia or in a part of Australia; or
a claim by a master, shipper, charterer or agent in respect of disbursements on account of a ship; or
a claim for an insurance premium, or for a mutual insurance call, in relation to a ship; or
a claim by a master, or a member of the crew of a ship for:
wages;

an amount that a person, as employer, is under an obligation to pay to a person as employee, whether the obligation arose out of the contract of employment or by operation of law, including the operation of the law of a foreign country; or

a claim for the enforcement of, or a claim arising out of, an arbitral award (including a foreign award within the meaning of the International Arbitration Act 1974 made in respect of a proprietary maritime claim or a claim referred to in one of the preceding paragraphs; or
a claim for interest in respect of a claim referred to in one of the preceding paragraphs.
[subs (3) am Act 73 of 2008 s 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 3 July 2008 ; Act 77 of 2008 s 3 and Sch 1[1]–[3], effective 16 June 2009]
Legislation cited in [250,015.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 4(2)(a)(iv).

For the purposes of s 4(2)(a)(iv) , if a mortgagee lawfully takes possession of a ship he or she is entitled to pay insurance premiums with respect to the ship and charge them against any freight he or she receives. However, if he or she does not take possession, any insurance premiums he or she pays cannot be added to the mortgage debt unless there is an express provision in the mortgage: The Basildon [1967] 2 Lloyd's Rep 134.
Legislation cited in [250,015.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 4(3)(a).

Although collision is the most common case the words in parenthesis in s 4(3)(a) demonstrate that actual physical contact between the ship and the object sustaining the damage is not essential: see also The Eschersheim [1976] 1 All ER 920; [1976] 1 WLR 430 at 438. The damage must be “done by a ship” thus it must be the direct result of something done in the actual navigation of the vessel, but damage constituted by financial loss may be sufficient even without actual physical damage: The Ama Antxine [1988] 1 Lloyd's Rep 431; see also [250,015.25] and [250,015.30] .

level.toc-caption: [250,015.15] Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981

heading.title: Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981

p.text: This Act imposes liability on a ship owner for pollution damage caused by oil that was discharged or escaped from a ship in Australian waters. The Act also provides a right to limit liability in the absence of fault or privity on the part of the ship owner.

level.toc-caption: [250,015.20] Loss caused by defect in a ship

p.text: Legislation cited in [250,015.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 4(3)(a), s 4(3)(c).

heading.title: Loss caused by defect in a ship

p.text: Where the ship itself is not the actual cause of the injury, so that the claim cannot come within s 4(3)(a) , the claim may nevertheless fall within s 4(3)(c) .

level.toc-caption: [250,015.25] Acts or omissions in the navigation or management of a ship

heading.title: Acts or omissions in the navigation or management of a ship

p.text: It is not necessary that the loss or injury in question should have occurred in connection with the actual navigation of the ship or indeed that it should have occurred on board ship. For example a claim for nervous shock suffered as a result of an injury to a person on the ship might be included. Furthermore the extension of jurisdiction to include acts or omissions in the management of a ship give rise to the possibility that it would include a claim by a passenger arising out of an assault by a member of the crew acting in the course of his or her employment could be brought. Secondly, it provides jurisdiction in rem for damage other than personal injury arising out of wrongdoing in the navigation or management of the vessel.

level.toc-caption: [250,015.30] Damage to goods carried by ship

p.text: Legislation cited in [250,015.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 3(3).

heading.title: Damage to goods carried by ship

p.text: Goods are defined in s 3(3) to include baggage and possessions that are to be carried on board a ship and would probably include the goods and possessions of employees on the ship.

level.toc-caption: [250,015.35] Agreement relating to carriage of goods

heading.title: Agreement relating to carriage of goods

p.text: It is not necessary that the parties to the claim are the same as the parties to the agreement in question: Samick Lines Co Ltd v Owners of The Antonas P Lemos [1985] 1 AC 711 at 731–3 (claim by sub-charterer against ship owners to recover compensation for additional expenses incurred by the sub-charterer as a result of the owners' negligence).
Legislation cited in [250,015.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 4(3)(f).

Under the Admiralty Court Act 1840 (UK) jurisdiction was expressed to relate to claims “in the nature of salvage”. The current head of jurisdiction (“a claim relating to salvage”) is wider and would, for example, include a claim for damages for breach of a salvage agreement and a claim in respect of negligently performed salvage (cf The Eschersheim [1976] 1 All ER 920; [1976] 1 WLR 430; The Tesaba [1982] 1 Lloyd's Rep 397; ALRC Report No 33, Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction, 1986, para 156). In any event these two examples would probably fall within s 4(3)(f) .
Legislation cited in [250,015.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 4(3)(f).

level.toc-caption: [250,015.50] Goods, materials or services supplied to a ship

heading.title: Goods, materials or services supplied to a ship

p.text: Unless the supply contract specifies the particular ship on which the goods will be used or the services supplied it does not fall within this paragraph: The River Rima [1988] 2 Lloyd's Rep 193 at 196.

level.toc-caption: [250,015.55] Disbursements on account of a ship

heading.title: Disbursements on account of a ship

p.text: A disbursement cannot be recovered against the ship unless it was properly incurred: The Tugot [1886] 11 PD 21.
Legislation cited in [250,015.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 s 4(3)(t)(ii).

The broad interpretation formerly given to “wages” has been strengthened by the express provisions in s 4(3)(t)(ii) . A claim by an allottee for wages is not included and must be brought in the ordinary courts: see ALRC, Report No 33, Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction, 1986, para 167.
Legislation cited in [250,015.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970.

Admiralty courts have also always had power to award prejudgment interest independently of provisions such as those contained in the Supreme Court Act 1970 : Shaw Savill & Albion Co Ltd v Commonwealth (1953) 88 CLR 164; 27 ALJR 130 . Except in special cases, the court's discretion to award interest will be exercised in conformity with the practice in other divisions of the court: RW Miller & Co Pty Ltd v The Ship Patris [1975] 1 NSWLR 704 at 707, 715, 717–8, 723–4. An award of salvage, which is peculiarly a subject of admiralty jurisdiction, may include an allowance for interest: Burley v The Texaco Southampton [1981] 2 NSWLR 239 at 249–50. The Act makes clear that the court has jurisdiction to award interest, including, for example, where the action is settled without judgment. Interest may be allowed for part only of the period after the cause of action arose where there is delay in the commencement or prosecution of the proceedings: Burley v The Texaco Southampton [1981] 2 NSWLR 239.
Subject to the succeeding provisions of this section, this Act applies in relation to:
all ships, irrespective of the places of residence or domicile of their owners; and
all maritime claims, wherever arising.
This Act does not apply in relation to a proceeding commenced before the commencement of this Act.
This Act does not apply in relation to a cause of action that arose:
in respect of an inland waterways vessel; or
in respect of the use or intended use of a ship on inland waters.
Paragraph (3)(b) does not have effect in relation to a cause of action if, at the time when the cause of action arose, the ship concerned was a foreign ship.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,025] s 6 Certain rights not created or affected

leg:heading.title: Certain rights not created or affected

p.text: a new maritime lien or other charge; or
a cause of action that would not have existed if this Act had not been passed.
This Act extends to each external Territory.
This Act binds the Crown in all its capacities.
This Act does not authorise:
a proceeding to be commenced as an action in rem against a government ship or government property; or
the arrest, detention or sale of a government ship or government property.

Where a proceeding has been commenced as an action in rem against a government ship or government property, the court may, if it is satisfied that the proceeding was so commenced in the reasonable belief that the ship was not a government ship, or the property was not government property:
order that the proceeding be treated as though it were a proceeding commenced as an action in personam on the claim against a person specified as defendant in the order; and
make such consequential orders as are necessary.
In this section:
means the Commonwealth, a State, the Northern Territory or the Administration of Norfolk Island;
means cargo or other property that belongs to a government, but does not include cargo or other property that belongs to a trading corporation that is an agency of a government;

means a ship that belongs, or is for the time being demised or sub-demised, to a government (including such a ship used by or in connection with a part of the Defence Force), but does not include a ship that belongs, or is for the time being demised or sub-demised, to a trading corporation that is an agency of a government.
Legislation cited in [250,035.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Foreign States Immunities Act 1985 s 18.
For actions against ships belonging to foreign states, see the Foreign States Immunities Act 1985 (Cth) s 18 .
